tit.cmt: タイトルなので大文字にしました。

sen.j: 日本の歴史（にほんのれきし）、日本史（にほんし）とは、日本または日本列島における歴史である。
sen.e: Nihon-no-rekisi (literally, Japanese history) or Nihonshi (literally, Japan history) is used for indicating history of Japan or that of the Japanese archipelago.
Nihon-no-rekisi (literally, Japanese history) or Nihonshi (literally, Japan history) is used for indicating history of Japan or that of the Japanese archipelago.

sen.j: 本項では日本の歴史を概観する。
sen.e: Here, a summary of Japanese history is described.

sen.j: 各時代の詳細は、各時代区分項目（各節の冒頭のリンク先）を参照されたい。
sen.e: For more information about each period, refer to the term for indicating the period (the link destination listed at the head of each section)

sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: 日本列島において確認されている人類の歴史は、約10万年ないし約3万年前までさかのぼる。
sen.e: The history of the human race that has been confirmed in the Japanese archipelago can be traced back to about 30 thousand to 100 thousand years ago.
The history of the human race confirmed in the Japanese archipelago can be traced back to about thirty thousand to one hundred thousand years ago.
The history of the human race confirmed in the Japanese archipelago can be traced back to about 30,000 to 100,000 years ago.

sen.j: 約3万4千年前に華北地方からナイフ形石器と呼ばれる石器が伝わり、列島全域で広く使用された。
sen.e: About 34 thousand years ago, stone tools called knife-type stone tools were brought to Japan from North China and were used throughout the Japanese islands.

sen.e: About thrity four thousand years ago, stone tools called knife-type stone tools were brought to Japan from Northern China and were used throughout the Japanese islands.

sen.j: それから、約2万年前にシベリアから新たに細石刃と呼ばれる石器が主に東日本に広まった。
sen.e: Then about 20 thousand ago, stone stools called microblades were brought to Japan from Siberia and were used mostly in eastern Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then about 20 thousand ago, stone stools called microblades were brought to Japan from Siberia and were used mostly in eastern Japan.

sen.j: しばらく東日本の細石刃文化と西日本のナイフ型石器文化が併存した。
sen.e: The microblade-based culture in eastern Japan and the knife-type stone tool-based culture in western Japan coexisted for some time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The microblade-based culture in eastern Japan and the knife-type stone tool-based culture in western Japan coexisted for some time.

sen.j: しかしながら、ほどなく細石刃が西日本にも広まり、約1万5千年前ごろ、ナイフ型石器は急速に姿を消した。
sen.e: However, before long, microblades became to be used widely in western Japan as well, and knife-type stone tools had become extinct rapidly until around 15 thousand years ago.

sen.e: However, before long, microblades came to be used widely in western Japan as well, and knife-type stone tools had gone out of use rapidly around fifteen thousand years ago.

sen.j: 約1万2千年前頃、最終氷期が終わり急激な温暖化による海面上昇が始まると、日本列島はアジア大陸から分離した。
sen.e: Around 12 thousand years ago, the ice period ended and the sea level began rising corresponding to rises in the atmospheric temperature, separating the Japanese islands from the Asian continent.
Around twelve thousand years ago, the ice age ended and the sea level began rising corresponding to rises in the atmospheric temperature, separating the Japanese islands from the Asian continent.
Around 12,000 years ago, the ice age ended and the sea level began rising corresponding to rises in the atmospheric temperature, separating the Japanese islands from the Asian continent.

sen.j: これにより、人々の文化や生活に大きな変化が生じ、南西諸島を除いて、次の縄文時代へ移行していった。
sen.e: Consequently, the lives and culture of the people living in the Japanese islands changed drastically, leading to the beginning of the Jomon period, except in the small islands in the southeast of the main islands of Japan.

Consequently, the life and culture of the people living in the Japanese islands changed drastically, leading to the beginning of the Jomon period, except for the small islands in the southeast of the main islands of Japan.

sen.j: 約1万2千年前頃からは縄文時代と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The period starting around 12 thousand years ago is called the Jomon period.
The period starting around twelve thousand years ago is called the Jomon period.
The period starting around 12,000 years ago is called the Jomon period.

sen.j: 草創期・早期・前期・中期・後期・晩期の6期に区分される。
sen.e: The Jomon period is classified into six sub-periods of the incipient period, earlier period, early period, middle period, end period and last period.
The Jomon period is classified into six sub-periods of the incipient period, earlier period, early period, middle period, end period, and last period.

sen.j: この頃の日本列島人は縄文式土器を作り、早期以降定住化が進んでおもに竪穴式住居に住んだ。
sen.e: In this period, people in the Japanese islands made Jomon-style earthenware, and increasing more people became to live in fixed places, mostly in pit dwellings.
During this period, people in the Japanese islands made Jomon-style earthenware, and increasingly more people came to live in fixed places, mostly in pit dwellings.

sen.j: 弓矢を用いた狩猟、貝塚に見られる漁労、植物の採集などで生活を営み、打製石器、磨製石器、骨角器などを用いた。
sen.e: People in this period lived the lives of hunting with bows and arrows, of fishing as known from shell mounds or of collecting fruits, and used chipped stone tools, polished stoneware and bone tools.
People in this period lived by hunting with bows and arrows, and fishing, as known from shell mounds or collecting fruit, and they used chipped stone tools, polished stoneware and bone tools.

sen.j: 栽培も行われ、後期から晩期にかけては稲作が行われた。
sen.e: Plants were cultivated as well, with rice cultivated in the end and last periods.
Plants were cultivated as well, with rice cultivated at the end and last periods.

sen.j: 南西諸島においてこの時期の前半は旧石器時代が継続していたが、約6千年前以降に貝塚時代に移行し、およそ平安時代末期まで続いた。
sen.e: In the small islands in the southeast of the main islands of Japan, lives were those of the Paleolithic Period in the first half of this period, but the shell mound period started around 60 thousand years ago and continued until around the end of the Heian period.

sen.j: 紀元前8世紀頃から3世紀頃までは弥生時代と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The era from around eighth B.C. to around third century is called the Yayoi period.
The era from around eight B.C. to around the third century is called the Yayoi period.
The era from around 8 B.C. to around the third century is called the Yayoi period.

sen.j: 時代区分名称は、この時期に特徴的に見られた弥生式土器に由来する。
sen.e: The term used for identifying this period is originated in Yayoi-style earthenware characteristic of this period.

sen.j: 稲作を中心とする農耕社会が成立し、北部九州から本州最北端以北を除く日本列島各地へ急速に広まった。
sen.e: Agriculture-based society centered on rice cultivation was established and spread rapidly to various parts of the Japanese islands, from the northern Kyushu area to the entire Honshu area, excluding the northernmost part of the Honshu area and the further northern area.

sen.j: 農耕社会の成立によって地域集団が形成された。
sen.e: The establishment of agriculture-based society generated local communities.
The establishment of an agriculture-based society generated local communities.
The establishment of an agriculture-based society generated local communities.

sen.j: 農耕社会の発展とともに地域集団は大型化していき、その中心部には環濠集落が営まれた。
sen.e: Corresponding to the advancement of the agriculture-based society, the sizes of the local communities had become larger, with a surrounded-by-moat settlement at their centers

sen.e: It is considered that many mound-type graves built in the period, whose style is one of the grave styles characteristic of the Mayor period, were for chiefs of these large-sized communities, and it is considered that the society began becoming hierarchical.

sen.j: 当時の日本列島は中国から倭・倭国と呼ばれた。
sen.e: The Japanese islands at that time was called Way or Awoke by China.

sen.j: 大型地域集団の中には中国王朝と通交するものもあり中国から「国」と称された。
sen.e: Some of these large-sized communities established a relationship with a Chinese dynasty, and were called a nation by China.

sen.j: 倭の奴国王は後漢へ通使し金印を授与された。
sen.e: The king of "Na of Way" sent his mission to the Later Han Dynasty and was given a golden stamp.

sen.j: 大型地域集団は次第に政治的な結合を強めていき、倭国連合と呼びうる政治連合体を2世紀初頭頃に形成した。
sen.e: The large-sized communities became to be united politically gradually, and a political confederation that could be called a union of Way nations was established in around the early second century.

sen.e: Its chief was called the king of Wa, and Suisho was the king of Wa in the early period of the confederation era.
Its chief was called the king of Wa, and Suisho was the king of Wa during the early period of the confederation era.

sen.j: しばらく倭国は政治的に安定していたが、2世紀後半に倭国大乱と呼ばれる内乱が生じた。
sen.e: For a while, Wa stayed stable politically, but a civil war called Wakoku War broke out in the latter half of the second century.

sen.e: In Hokkaido and the northern Tohoku area, rice cultivation in paddy fields was not acceptable and lives there changed into those in the post Jomon period.

sen.j: 3世紀中後半から7世紀頃までは古墳時代と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The era from the latter half of third century to around the seventh century is called the kofun period (tumulus period).

sen.e: Large keyhole-shaped tomb mounds appeared in around the middle of third century and use of the grave style spread rapidly throughout the islands of Japan.

sen.j: 4世紀後半からヤマト王権は、武器・農具の原料である鉄資源を求めて朝鮮半島への進出を開始したが、これを契機として朝鮮半島や中国の技術・文物が倭国へ多く流入することとなった。
sen.e: Starting in the latter half of the fourth century, the Yamato sovereignty began to advance into the Korean peninsula, seeking for iron needed for making weapons and farm tools, causing many technologies and cultural products in the Korean peninsular and China to be introduced to Wa.

sen.e: Entering the fifth century, the Yamato sovereignty moved its core site to the Kawachi plain and had active relationships with the Chinese dynasty.

sen.j: 6世紀末、400年ぶりに中国を統一した隋の登場は、東アジア諸国の政治権力の集中化をもたらした。
sen.e: Towards the end of the sixth century, Sui Dynasty unified China in 400 years, centralizing political powers in east Asian nations.

sen.e: Towards the end of the sixth century, the Sui Dynasty unified China in four hundred years, centralizing political powers in east Asian nations.

sen.j: 倭国でも7世紀前半にかけて聖徳太子と蘇我氏により遣隋使派遣・冠位十二階制定・十七条憲法導入などの国政改革が行われた。
sen.e: In Wa as well, Prince Shotoku and the Soga clan reformed national politics through sending Japanese envoys to Sui Dynasty China, establishing Kani junikai (twelve grades of cap rank) and introducing Seventeen-Article Constitution.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: しかし豪族層の抵抗も根強く、権力集中化はその後も企図されたが、その動きは伸び悩んだ。
sen.e: However, powerful families were still strongly resistant, and the move to concentrate powers was stagnant, though attempted later as well.

sen.j: 7世紀中ごろの大化の改新も権力集中化の動きの一つであり、一定の進展を見せている。
sen.e: The Taika Reforms in around the middle of the seventh century was such a move to strengthen powers, achieving a certain level of advancement.

sen.j: しかし、権力集中化への最大の契機は、7世紀後半の百済復興戦争における敗北（→白村江の戦い）であった。
sen.e: However, the largest opportunity for centralizing powers was provided with the defeat in the Kudara restoration war in the latter half of seventh century (-> Battle of Hakusonko (Battle of Baekgang)).

sen.j: 倭国内の諸勢力は国制整備を進めることで一致し、権力集中化が急速に進み始めた。
sen.e: Various powers in Wa consented to the reformation of national systems, accelerating the speed of centralizing power.

sen.e: Furthermore, Ｅmperor Tenmu who wan the Jinshin war concentrated power thoroughly and attempted to deify Emperor.

sen.j: 併せて、天皇支配を具現化するために律令制の導入を進め、8世紀初頭の大宝律令制定に結実した。
sen.e: In addition, the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) was introduced to realize control by Emperor, producing Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) in the early eighth century.

sen.j: なお、この時期北海道中西南部・青森県北部においては擦文時代を迎える。
sen.e: In this era, lives in the middle and southwestern areas of Hokkaido and the northern part of Aomori Prefecture entered the Satsumon Period (featured by earthenware with patterns called Satsumon).

sen.j: 8世紀初頭から末にかけては奈良時代と呼ばれ、奈良に都城（平城京）が置かれた。
sen.e: The era from the early eight century to the end of it is called the Nara period, because the capital (Heijo-kyo capital) was placed in Nara.

sen.j: この時期は、律令国家体制の形成と深化が図られた。
sen.e: In this period, a Ritsuryo-based national system was formed and advanced.
During this period, a Ritsuryo-based national system was formed and advanced.

sen.j: 王土王民思想に基づく律令制は、天皇とその官僚による一元的な支配を志向しており、民衆に対しては編戸制・班田制・租庸調制・軍団 (古代日本)などの支配が行われた。
sen.e: The Ritsuryo system based on Odo omin shiso (the thought that all the land and people belong to the emperor) intended unified control of the nation by Emperor and national government officials, and the people was controlled through henko-sei (a system for organizing the people), handen-sei (a land-allotment system based on Ritsuryo), Soyocho system (a tax system, corvee) and troops (in ancient Japan).

sen.j: 8世紀前半は、律令制強化への動きが積極的に展開された。
sen.e: In the first half of the eight century, the move for strengthening the Ritsuryo system was made actively.

sen.j: 三世一身法・墾田永年私財法などの農地拡大政策もこうした律令制強化の一環だったと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that the policies to increase arable land, such as Sanze-isshin Law (a law allowing farmers who created new arable lands to own them for a period of three generations) and Konden einen shizai Law (a law allowing farmers who created new arable lands to own them permanently), were for supporting the strengthening of the Ritsuryo system.

sen.j: しかし、8世紀後半に入ると、百姓階層の分化が始まり、百姓の逃亡が増加するなど、律令支配の転換を迫る状況が生じていった。

sen.j: また、新羅を蕃国とし、東北地方の蝦夷・南九州の隼人を化外民とする中華意識が高まった。
sen.e: In addition, China-centered consciousness, in which Silla was considered a barbarian country and Emishi in the northeastern area as well as Hayato in the southern Kyushu area were considered kegaimin (outsiders), heightened.

sen.j: 日本は、新羅へ朝貢を要求するとともに、蝦夷・隼人らを「教化」して律令支配へと組み込もうとしていった。
sen.e: In Japan, the government demanded that Silla should bring tributes to Japan and also tried to enlighten Emishi and Hayato to be integrated into the control based on the Ritsuryo system.

sen.e: In the aspect of culture, "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and "Fudoki" (descriptions of regional climate, culture, etc.) were compiled.

sen.j: 仏教では鎮護国家思想が強まり、聖武天皇の発願で東大寺・国分寺が国家護持の名目で建立された。
sen.e: In Buddhism, nation protection thought was strengthened, and Todai-ji Temple and Kokubun-ji Temples were constructed at the wish of Emperor Shomu on the pretext of kokka goji (defending and maintaining the nation).

sen.j: 8世紀末頃から12世紀末頃までは平安時代と呼ばれ、桓武天皇の築いた平安京が都とされた。
sen.e: The era from around the end of the eighth century to around the end of 12th century is called the Heian period, with the Heian-kyo constructed by Emperor Kanmu as the national capital.

sen.j: 平安前期には百姓階層の分化が一層進み、前代から引き続いた律令国家体制に限界が生じていた。

sen.j: そこで政府は11世紀初頭ごろから地方分権的な国家体制改革を精力的に推進し、王朝国家と呼ばれる体制が成立した。
sen.e: Therefore, starting in the early eleventh century, the national government promoted the reformation of the national system actively through decentralization, establishing a system called a dynastic nation-state.

sen.j: 王朝国家では、大幅に統治権限を委譲された受領とその国衙機構による地方支配が展開した。
sen.e: In the dynastic nation-state, Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors), to whom a considerable amount of the right to control the province was transferred, and its kokuga (provincial government offices) controlled local areas.

sen.e: The number of shoen (private estates) had increased considerably from around the end of the twelfth century to the early thirteenth century, and a medieval control system called shoen koryo sei (a system of public lands and private estates) was established.

sen.e: Nobunaga ODA ousted Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, the shogun in Muromachi, and established the Kinai government (the government in the Kinai area (roughly corresponding to the present Kansai region)) replacing the Muromachi bakufu.

sen.e: Based on the Kinai government established by Nobunaga, Hideyoshi conquered the areas from Tohoku to Kyushu, completing the job of unifying the control of Japan.

sen.j: 秀吉もまた中世的支配体系・支配勢力の排除・抑制に努めた。

sen.j: 秀吉は文禄・慶長の役を実行したが、その最中に死去し、後継者問題も抱えていた豊臣政権は弱体化した。

sen.e: After Hideyoshi unified control of Japan, stabilizing the politics and economy, the magnificent Momoyama culture flourished centered on daimyo and samurai.

sen.j: 慶長8年（1603年）から慶応3年（1867年）までは江戸時代と呼ばれ、江戸に江戸幕府が置かれた。
sen.e: The era from 1603 to 1867 is called the Edo period, and the Edo bakufu was placed in Edo.

sen.j: 秀吉の死後、徳川家康は関ヶ原の戦いに勝利して権力を掌握した。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi died, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA took over power through the win of the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.j: この後幕府は、17世紀中葉までに、武家諸法度の発布や参勤交代の義務化、有力大名の改易などを通して、諸大名との主従制を確固たるものとし、朝廷統制を強め、幕府官僚機構を整備した。
sen.e: After this, the bakufu solidified the master-servant relationship with each daimyo by around the middle of 17th century, through enacting Buke shohatto (laws for the military households), making Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo) obligatory, and conducting Kaieki operations (forfeiting the rank of samurai and properties) for powerful daimyo, strengthened control of the Imperial Court, and established its government officer system.

sen.j: 並行して、キリスト教の制限と貿易の管理強化をすすめ、社会の安定化に努めた。
sen.e: In parallel, the bakufu made efforts to stabilize the society through restricting Christianity-related activities and strengthening control of trade.

sen.j: そうした中勃発した島原・天草一揆は、キリスト教禁止の徹底と、幕府による管理貿易である鎖国の完成へとつながる。
sen.e: In such a situation, the occurrence of Shimabara/Amakusa uprisings led the bakufu to the complete prohibition of Christianity and the complete national isolation that allowed only the bakufu-controlled trade.

sen.j: 日本の境界領域である琉球王国と蝦夷地（和人地である渡島半島を除く北海道、樺太及び千島列島）の支配は大名を通じて行なわれた。
sen.e: The Ryukyu Kingdom and the Ezo area (the Hokkaido areas except the Oshima peninsula occupied by wajin (Japanese: persons whose origin was in the Japanese main lands), Sakhalin and Kurile Islands) were controlled through the Daimyo concerned.

sen.j: 一方で、社会の安定化に伴い、耕地開発の大事業が各地で実施された。

sen.e: Doubling the arable land increased the population as well as the amount of food produced, supporting the finance of the bakufu and that of each domain through the murauke system (village-wide, collective responsibility for tax payment) and advancing nation-wide distribution-related economy greatly.

sen.j: 同後半の黒船来航と日米和親条約締結を契機として、幕府の管理貿易体制（鎖国）は解かれ、結果として幕府の威信は低下し、朝廷の権威が増大した。
sen.e: With the arrival of Kurofune (the black ships of Commodore Matthew Perry) and the conclusion of Treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan as the turning point, the trade system controlled by the bakufu (Sakoku) was dissolved, resultantly lowering the authority of the bakufu and increasing the authority of the Imperial Court.

The Meiji period

sen.j: 明治年間（1868年 - 1912年）は明治と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The era from 1868 to 1912 is called the Meiji period.
The era from 1868 to 1912 is called the Meiji period.

sen.j: 倒幕派の諸藩を中心とする維新政府は戊辰戦争を経て旧幕府勢力を退けると、明治新政府を樹立した。
sen.e: The restoration government centered on the domains for overthrowing the bakufu expelled the former bakufu powers via the Boshin Civil War, and then established the new Meiji government.

sen.j: 新政府は天皇大権のもと欧米の諸制度を積極的に導入し、廃藩置県、身分解放、法制整備、国家インフラの整備など明治維新と呼ばれる一連の改革を遂行した。
sen.e: Under Emperor's power, the new government introduced various systems from European countries and the United States, and made a set of reformations called Maiji Restoration, such as Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), abolition of the class system, establishment of the law system and construction of national infrastructures.

sen.j: その過程で日本の境界領域であった旧琉球王国領域や、樺太を除く蝦夷地（北海道の大部分と千島列島）、小笠原諸島を完全に日本の領域内におき、国境を画定した。
sen.e: In the process, the government placed the former Ryukyu Kingdom, the Ezo area except Sakhalin (almost all areas of Hokkaido and Kurile Islands) and Ogasawara Islands (Bonin Islands) completely into the Japanese territories, fixing the boundaries of Japan.

sen.j: 新政府は不平等条約の改正を目指し、帝国議会の設置や大日本帝国憲法の制定など国制整備に努めた。
sen.e: Aiming at revising the unequal treaties, the new government made efforts to establish the national systems, such as the establishment of Imperial Diet and the enactment of the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

sen.e: However, roughly it can be said that classifying the periods into (the primitive period), ancient times, the medieval period, the early-modern times, modern times, and the contemporary period is widely accepted in the researches of history.

sen.e: On the other hand, in the latter half of the Edo period, as the bakufu-domain system became unmatched with needs at that time and pressure from foreign nations had heightened, interests for history had increased among general public as well, and many popular histories, such as "Nihon Gaishi" (historical book on Japan) and "Kochoshiryaku" (brief history book about emperors from Jinmu to Gokomatsu), were published.

sen.e: In the era from around the end of the Edo period to Meiji Restoration, modern European history, such as history of civilization, had been brought to Japan rapidly, and in particular, progressive views of history and evolutionary views of history had become well known rapidly.

sen.j: これは日本史と西欧史の共通点を強調する方向へ進でいった。
sen.e: Activities in this line progressed towards emphasizing points common to Japanese history and European history.

sen.j: 一方、明治政府の立場からは、天皇を中心とする国民国家を建設するため、国家主義的な歴史叙述が構築されていった。
sen.e: On the other hand, from the viewpoint of building a nation-state centered on Emperor, the Meiji government developed nationalistic descriptions of history.

sen.e: This constituted the view of history to legitimize Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) and the restoration of imperial rule.

sen.e: Therefore, the Taika Reforms, Kenmu Restoration and Meiji Restoration were positioned as the most important reformations, and these nationalistic views of history had been actively introduced, in particular, into actual education of history.

sen.e: Thus, two flows of thoughts, the direction of trying to find universality in history and the direction of emphasizing uniqueness of Japanese history, can be found in the recognition of history and descriptions of history in the Meiji period and later.

sen.e: In 1887, Ludwig Riess, a disciple of Leopold von Ranke, the founder of positivism-based history, was invited to Imperial University.

sen.e: Riess taught strict positivism-based history, formed so-called government-led academism, but had the tendency of placing too much emphasis on checking historical evidences.

sen.e: Towards the end of the Meiji period, evolution phase-based views of history was advocated affected by the German historical school, and materialistic views of history based on Marxism was introduced to Japan as well.

sen.e: Entering the Taisho period, the historical theory (by Kant and Dilthey) strongly denying the concept of considering that history progresses according to a law, a concept strongly supported in Marxism-based materialistic views of history, was introduced, staring strengthening interests in the philosophy of history.
